prior_works.title: Partitioned Variational Inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FedGVI explicitly generalises PVI by replacing its KL-based site updates with robust, generalized VI objectives and by rederiving cavity/aggregation rules that yield conjugate and computationally cheaper client updates.

prior_works.title: Generalized Variational Inference
prior_works.authors: Jeremias Knoblauch, Jack Jewson, Theodoros Damoulas
prior_works.role: Foundational theory for robustness under misspecification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FedGVI instantiates the GVI principle at the client level—optimizing generalized Bayes/score-based objectives—to achieve calibrated uncertainty and robustness to likelihood (and prior) misspecification in federated settings.

prior_works.title: A general framework for updating belief distributions
prior_works.authors: Pier Giovanni Bissiri, Chris C. Holmes, Stephen G. Walker
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The generalized posterior construction of Bissiri et al. under proper scoring rules underpins FedGVI’s use of loss-based posteriors and its theoretical guarantees for well-calibrated predictions under model misspecification.

prior_works.title: Expectation Propagation for Approximate Bayesian Inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FedGVI’s cavity distribution, fixed-point characterisation, and site-wise message passing build on EP’s cavity/tilted distribution concepts, adapted to generalized VI objectives and federated aggregation.

prior_works.title: Conjugate-Computation Variational Inference: Converting Variational Inference in Non-Conjugate Models to Conjugate
prior_works.role: Algorithmic enabler for conjugate client updates
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FedGVI’s ability to realize conjugate, closed-form updates at clients—reducing on-device computation—follows the CVI idea of recasting nonconjugate updates into conjugate computations via natural-parameter mirror descent.

prior_works.title: A Bayesian Committee Machine
prior_works.relationship_sentence: FedGVI’s principled aggregation of client contributions exploits the product-of-experts/posterior factorization perspective introduced by the BCM, aligning local site factors with a global posterior through cavity corrections.

synthesis_narrative:
FedGVI sits at the intersection of distributed Bayesian inference and robust variational objectives. Its federated architecture and message-passing mechanics directly extend Partitioned Variational Inference, retaining the partitioned/site view and cavity distribution while broadening the update class beyond standard KL-based VI. This generalization is enabled by Generalized Variational Inference and the generalized Bayes framework of Bissiri et al., which justify replacing likelihood-based objectives with proper scoring rules or divergence-robust losses. These foundations provide FedGVI with calibrated uncertainty and robustness to both likelihood and prior misspecification, addressing a key shortcoming of conventional Bayesian and frequentist FL.

On the algorithmic side, FedGVI leverages the conjugate-computation insights of CVI to translate generalized, potentially nonconjugate local objectives into tractable conjugate updates, thereby lowering client-side computational burden and communication cost. The paper’s analysis of cavity optimality and fixed-point convergence traces to Expectation Propagation, whose cavity/tilted constructs guide FedGVI’s site updates and theoretical guarantees; FedGVI adapts these constructs to generalized objectives. Finally, the Bayesian Committee Machine’s product-of-experts view provides the principled blueprint for composing client contributions into a coherent global posterior via cavity corrections, now executed under generalized VI losses. Together, these works yield a federated probabilistic framework that unifies partitioned/distributed inference with robust generalized Bayes, offering both theoretical robustness under misspecification and practical, conjugate updates suitable for heterogeneous federated environments.
